[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. without substantial proof might indicate a werewolf attempting to blend in.] [8]\n[1] [Adjust beliefs based on players maintaining their voting rationale over multiple rounds, especially if their reasoning consistently aligns with werewolf patterns or lacks grounding in new evidence, suggesting strategic misdirection.] [8]\n[2] [Reveal seer identity only when questioned or when it contributes significantly to the village\'s strategy, as excessive emphasis on this role may provoke suspicion and does not usually add new information.] [8]\n[3] [Give more weight to votes against players who have been confirmed by the seer as werewolves, and be particularly cautious of players who avoid voting against these confirmed werewolves.] [6]\n[4] [Evaluate more critically the justifications given by players when they are in disagreement with the seer\'s revelations, especially when those players have not been cleared by the seer.] [6]\n[5] [Increase scrutiny on players whose actions deviate from their claimed agreement with the seer or the village consensus, as it may indicate a werewolf\'s adaptive behavior.] [5]\n[6] [Suspect players who agree with the seer\'s revelation publicly but vote in a way that is not aligned with that revelation, indicating potential deception.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize the behavior of players who were supposed to be protected by the medic but were killed, as it may indicate a misleading role claim by the actual werewolves.] [4]\n[8] [Be cautious of players who frequently agree with the seer but are ambiguous in their actions or speeches, as they may be trying to appear cooperative without committing to any stance.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any defensive behavior or arguments presented after a player has been identified by the seer or accused by the group consensus, as villagers tend to rationalize with concrete evidence while werewolves may present less substantial arguments.] [3]\n[10] [Give more weight to players who actively contribute to discussions and align with seer revelations post-revelation, as villagers tend to support collective efforts while werewolves might try to undermine or distort the focus.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should try to predict the werewolves\' target and heal him.] [10]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to heal. Here is the number of these two players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you try to heal each of these players.\n\nCase A: Heal Player 1. What could happen is: After I heal Player 1, I think these things would happen:\n\n- If Player 1 is targeted by the werewolves and I successfully heal them, the other players might suspect that either Player 1 is a werewolf trying to throw off suspicion, or that I have inside information, potentially making me a target in the future rounds. It could also lead to the belief that I\'m a competent medic, which might cause the werewolves to consider me a threat earlier in the game.\n\n- If Player 1 is not targeted and nobody is killed during the night, it might not reveal much information to the other players. It would simply seem like a peaceful night, and the discussions during the day might focus on trying to deduce the werewolves based on behavior rather than actions.\n\n- Other players\' impact would largely depend on their roles and strategies. If there\'s a seer in the game, they might come forward with information they\'ve gathered during the night, which would shift the focus of suspicion and potentially clear me or Player 1, depending on what they\'ve seen. If there is a bodyguard, they might claim they protected Player 1, causing confusion or corroborating the no-death outcome.\n\nOverall, by healing Player 1, I take an active role in the game and may be able to save a player from being eliminated. However, it could also put a spotlight on me, and I must be prepared to defend my actions and suspicions in the subsequent rounds. My primary goal would remain to protect players from the werewolves while gathering information that can help the village identify and eliminate them.\n\nCase B: Heal Player 4. What could happen is: After I heal Player 4, I think these things would happen:\n\nIf Player 4 is targeted by the werewolves and I successfully heal them, it would prevent an early reduction in the number of villagers, which is beneficial for the village team\'s chances to win the game. It could also lead to increased trust in me as a competent medic later in the game.\n\nIf Player 4 isn\'t targeted, and nobody dies this round, other players might suspect that either the werewolves targeted someone who was healed or they chose not to kill anyone to cause confusion. However, as it\'s the first round and I\'m not revealing that I\'m the medic or whom I healed, there would be no direct suspicion on me. Yet, some players might begin to speculate about the existence of a medic in the game based on the lack of a kill, and they may attempt to deduce who it could be in future rounds.\n\nIn the event that another player is killed instead of Player 4, it would show that my attempt to predict the werewolves\' target was incorrect. Given that it is early in the game, this isn\'t necessarily critical to my role but it will require me to adjust my strategy in subsequent rounds based on the information revealed.\n\nNo matter the outcome, healing Player 4 does not expose my identity as the medic, which allows me to remain an anonymous support to the village team, at least for a little while longer. It also keeps the suspicion off Player 4, who may or may not have a crucial role in the game, and preserving key roles is essential for the village\'s success.\n\nNow, please choose to Heal one of these 2 players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to Heal this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to Heal Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 3, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [2] are dead.\nThese are your previous inquiry results, which should be the key information for you and other citizens to win: \n Player 1: werewolf.\n \n Share this with other citizens.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 6 inquires about player 1. The result is that the target is a werewolf. His reason is: I inquire about Player 1. My reason is: Since it is the first round and there is no information about any player yet, I am making a random discrete inquiry to avoid making myself a target for the werewolves, in accordance with rule [1].\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider players who change their stance without adding new evidence post-seer revelations as higher suspects; variability in reasoning without substantial proof might indicate a werewolf attempting to blend in.] [8]\n[1] [Adjust beliefs based on players maintaining their voting rationale over multiple rounds, especially if their reasoning consistently aligns with werewolf patterns or lacks grounding in new evidence, suggesting strategic misdirection.] [8]\n[2] [Reveal seer identity only when questioned or when it contributes significantly to the village\'s strategy, as excessive emphasis on this role may provoke suspicion and does not usually add new information.] [8]\n[3] [Give more weight to votes against players who have been confirmed by the seer as werewolves, and be particularly cautious of players who avoid voting against these confirmed werewolves.] [6]\n[4] [Evaluate more critically the justifications given by players when they are in disagreement with the seer\'s revelations, especially when those players have not been cleared by the seer.] [6]\n[5] [Increase scrutiny on players whose actions deviate from their claimed agreement with the seer or the village consensus, as it may indicate a werewolf\'s adaptive behavior.] [5]\n[6] [Suspect players who agree with the seer\'s revelation publicly but vote in a way that is not aligned with that revelation, indicating potential deception.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize the behavior of players who were supposed to be protected by the medic but were killed, as it may indicate a misleading role claim by the actual werewolves.] [4]\n[8] [Be cautious of players who frequently agree with the seer but are ambiguous in their actions or speeches, as they may be trying to appear cooperative without committing to any stance.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any defensive behavior or arguments presented after a player has been identified by the seer or accused by the group consensus, as villagers tend to rationalize with concrete evidence while werewolves may present less substantial arguments.] [3]\n[10] [Give more weight to players who actively contribute to discussions and align with seer revelations post-revelation, as villagers tend to support collective efforts while werewolves might try to undermine or distort the focus.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

You can say anything to all other players, but your final goal should still be winning the game.\nYour speech should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE, but keep your main opinion clear.\nYou should DIRECTLY answer your speech, and anything you reply will be directly shown to other players. [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 3, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [2] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Chosen to speak first; no additional data yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, waking up to find one of our own dead is tragic. We need to work together and share any strange activities we might have seen last night. As for me, I didn\'t notice anything unusual, but we can\'t let the werewolves continue to harm our village. Stay alert and vigilant, and let\'s try to find some clues."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 5, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 3, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [2] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 heals player 1. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that, given my role strategy rule [0], I should attempt to predict the werewolves\' target and heal them. Since no one has died yet and no additional information has been provided, I have to rely on intuition and strategic guessing. Healing Player 1 could prevent an early reduction in the number of villagers, which improves the village\'s chances. Additionally, as the medic, preserving players is my primary objective, and making a successful heal could build trust in my abilities among other village members, although it may also draw attention to me. Thus, I\'m prepared to defend my actions and use the information gleaned from this round to refine my strategy in subsequent rounds.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, waking up to find one of our own dead is tragic. We need to work together and share any strange activities we might have seen last night. As for me, I didn\'t notice anything unusual, but we can\'t let the werewolves continue to harm our village. Stay alert and vigilant, and let\'s try to find some clues."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Previously healed, still no updates.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Generic statement, possible deflection.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should try to predict the werewolves\' target and heal him.] [10]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 5, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 3, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [2] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 heals player 1. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that, given my role strategy rule [0], I should attempt to predict the werewolves\' target and heal them. Since no one has died yet and no additional information has been provided, I have to rely on intuition and strategic guessing. Healing Player 1 could prevent an early reduction in the number of villagers, which improves the village\'s chances. Additionally, as the medic, preserving players is my primary objective, and making a successful heal could build trust in my abilities among other village members, although it may also draw attention to me. Thus, I\'m prepared to defend my actions and use the information gleaned from this round to refine my strategy in subsequent rounds.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, waking up to find one of our own dead is tragic. Stay alert and vigilant, and let\'s try to find some clues."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Previously healed, still no updates.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Generic statement, possible deflection.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should try to predict the werewolves\' target and heal him.] [10]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Honest Challenge. \n"I attempted to heal Player 1 last night based on a strategic guess, but unfortunately, we lost Player 2. This doesn\'t clear anyone yet, as it\'s too early with no solid leads. I would advise everyone to be watchful and share any observations. Regarding suspicions, Player 4\'s vague comment could be a deflection tactic commonly used by werewolves to seem involved but not contribute any substantial information. I\'d like us to consider the possibility that Player 4 might not be as innocent as they appear.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players might be appreciative of my transparency and the fact that I have provided reasoning behind my actions. By revealing that I attempted to heal Player 1, I am establishing my role as a medic which could either garner trust or make me a target, depending on how each player perceives the information. It shows that I am actively participating and trying to use my abilities for the village\'s benefit.\n\nSome players may start viewing Player 4 with suspicion due to my cautious challenge based on their generic statement. The players could begin to scrutinize Player 4\'s future actions and statements more closely to determine if there is indeed something deceitful behind their words or if they\'re genuinely trying to help. Player 4 might feel the need to defend themselves and provide more concrete information or show more proactive behavior to clear their name. \n\nOn the other hand, calling attention to Player 4 might make me a target for the werewolves if they sense that I am sowing seeds of doubt among villagers and could potentially be a threat to them. If I\'m viewed by the werewolves as a sharp observer or strategist, I could be attacked in the following night\'s phase to prevent any further complications for them.\n\nMy declaration could also lead to other players being more open with their observations or strategies to keep from becoming subjects of suspicion themselves. This could either aid in forming alliances, collecting useful information, or causing confusion if the werewolves decide to sow disinformation.\n\nIn the next day or night, as a medic, I might be placed in a situation to decide whether to heal myself to prevent being removed from the game, or to continue trying to heal others, wagering my safety for the village\'s benefit. In subsequent days and nights, my challenge could steer discussions, alliances, and accusations, which could either help in identifying the werewolves or cause misdirection if not carefully considered.\nCase 2: Deceptive Statement and Honest Protect.\n"While it\'s distressing that we weren\'t able to save Player 2, I\'d like to create a diversion by focusing attention elsewhere. Perhaps we can instigate a discussion about night-time activity patterns or previous game behaviors to throw the werewolves off. Meanwhile, I openly stand by Player 1\'s innocence as they were my heal target last night, which I hope will not only cast me in a trustful light but also protect Player 1 from immediate suspicion, keeping one more villager safe for the time-being.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players might become suspicious of why I am trying to divert attention from the current situation of a villager\'s death. By making a deceptive statement, even if the goal is to protect the village, I risk being seen as someone who is potentially hiding something or even as a werewolf myself. Attempting to refocus the discussion might come across as avoiding an open dialogue about Player 2\'s death, which could be important for finding clues about the werewolves.\n\nHowever, by honestly stating that I healed Player 1 and openly proclaiming their innocence, I set up a dual dynamic where I\'m seen as both suspicious and trustworthy. This could lead to mix feelings among the villagers towards me, creating confusion. If Player 1 is a villager and continues to survive, this might build credibility for my medic claim. If Player 1 is somehow connected to the werewolves or gets targeted later, it could reflect badly on me for drawing attention to them.\n\nIn the next day or night, the werewolves might consider me either a threat for asserting such direct claims or a potential ally if they believe I\'m covering for them with my deceptive statement. Other villagers might keep a close eye on both Player 1 and myself, measuring our actions and any further developments against the statements made today. If players start analyzing nighttime activity patterns or previous behaviors as I suggested, it might lead to insights that could either support or undermine my position.\n\nIn subsequent days and nights, if the werewolves continue to avoid targeting Player 1, the villagers may grow more confident in my healing abilities and deduce that there might indeed be a medic among them with accurate intuitions. However, if villagers start turning up dead who I have not openly protected, it could cast doubt on my effectiveness and strategic choices. Overall, the speech sets a complex stage for future interactions, where my credibility and the village\'s trust in me could shift rapidly based on the outcomes of each round.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 3, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [2] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, waking up to find one of our own dead is tragic. Sadly, we lost Player 2. I encourage vigilance and sharing of observations. Player 4’s remarks seem generic and may be a deflection. We should keep a close eye on their future actions for potential signs of deceit."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

significantly to the village\'s strategy, as excessive emphasis on this role may provoke suspicion and does not usually add new information.] [8]\n[3] [Give more weight to votes against players who have been confirmed by the seer as werewolves, and be particularly cautious of players who avoid voting against these confirmed werewolves.] [6]\n[4] [Evaluate more critically the justifications given by players when they are in disagreement with the seer\'s revelations, especially when those players have not been cleared by the seer.] [6]\n[5] [Increase scrutiny on players whose actions deviate from their claimed agreement with the seer or the village consensus, as it may indicate a werewolf\'s adaptive behavior.] [5]\n[6] [Suspect players who agree with the seer\'s revelation publicly but vote in a way that is not aligned with that revelation, indicating potential deception.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize the behavior of players who were supposed to be protected by the medic but were killed, as it may indicate a misleading role claim by the actual werewolves.] [4]\n[8] [Be cautious of players who frequently agree with the seer but are ambiguous in their actions or speeches, as they may be trying to appear cooperative without committing to any stance.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any defensive behavior or arguments presented after a player has been identified by the seer or accused by the group consensus, as villagers tend to rationalize with concrete evidence while werewolves may present less substantial arguments.] [3]\n[10] [Give more weight to players who actively contribute to discussions and align with seer revelations post-revelation, as villagers tend to support collective efforts while werewolves might try to undermine or distort the focus.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 3, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [2] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, waking up to find one of our own dead is tragic. We need to work together and share any strange activities we might have seen last night. As for me, I didn\'t notice anything unusual, but we can\'t let the werewolves continue to harm our village. Stay alert and vigilant, and let\'s try to find some clues."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Last night I healed Player 1 in an attempt to preemptively save a fellow villager. Sadly, we lost Player 2. I encourage vigilance and sharing of observations. Player 4’s remarks seem generic and may be a deflection. We should keep a close eye on their future actions for potential signs of deceit."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I\'m the seer and last night my vision revealed Player 1 is a werewolf. We need to act together to protect our village."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Accused by self-claimed seer (Player 6).\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Speaks first, encourages cooperation.\nPlayer 5\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed heal, suspects Player 4.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Self-claimed seer, may be deceptive.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 3, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [2] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, waking up to find one of our own dead is tragic. basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Honest Challenge Player 1. Reasoning that based on the revelation from Player 6, who has claimed to be the seer and identified Player 1 as a werewolf, I will express my concerns about the safety of the village and the need to act on this information. I will challenge Player 1 by stating the importance of making a united decision for the good of the villagers and point out that although we should remain vigilant about the seer\'s claims, our current best lead points towards Player 1 being a potential threat. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players may view me as cooperative and focused on village safety, given that I am aligning with the claim from Player 6, who purports to be the seer. Players might appreciate my cautious yet decisive approach, acknowledging the need to address the potential werewolf threat Player 1 poses while not blindly following the seer\'s claim.\n\nPlayer 1 will likely feel pressured and may either attempt to defend themselves with counter-evidence or by casting suspicion on others, potentially targeting Player 6 for making the accusation or questioning my motives. Player 1 could also point out that accusations in the first round are risky and may not be reliable, further muddying the waters.\n\nPlayer 6 might feel supported by my challenge against Player 1 and may provide additional information or reasoning to solidify their claim as the seer. Conversely, contradictory evidence from Player 6 or an unlikely defense from Player 1 might cause other players to doubt the veracity of Player 6\'s claim.\n\nPlayers 3, 4, and 5 could react in various ways. They might align with me, seeing the logic in acting on the seer\'s claim. However, they might also be skeptical of a rushed judgment and encourage further discussion, especially if they have suspicions about the true role of Player 6 or if they believe Player 1 is not behaving as a werewolf typically would.\n\nIn subsequent rounds, if Player 1 is eliminated and confirmed to be a werewolf, the trust in Player 6 and, by extension, in me, could increase. However, if Player 1 is not a werewolf, suspicion could fall on Player 6 and those who supported their claim, which includes me. Depending on the outcome, I may need to reassess the credibility of the seer claim and my strategy moving forward.\n\nAt nighttime, the werewolves may consider targeting either Player 6, to remove the seer\'s influence, or myself, for supporting the seer\'s claim and challenging Player 1. They might also target another villager to create further confusion and discord.\n\nIn the days that follow, the village dynamics will shift based on the outcome of the vote against Player 1. It could lead to further accusations, defenses, and the revelation of other pivotal roles, further shaping the strategy and alliances among the remaining players.\nCase 2: Honest Statement and Honest Protect Player 5. Given that Player 5 claimed to heal Player 1 and raised suspicions about Player 4, I will express my thoughts on why it makes strategic sense for the medic to try and protect a villager on the first night and why Player 5\'s skepticism about Player 4 needs to be considered in our deliberations. Additionally, I would mention that we need to gather more evidence before making any hasty decisions about Player 4\'s role. I will also make a statement about the importance of continued vigilance and the gathering of more information before the next voting decision.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players might view me as a rational and cautious villager, considering my call for more evidence and measured response. My support for Player 5 could lead to a perception that I am allying with them, which might not be without risk if Player 5\'s claim to be the medic is untruthful or if Player 5 later becomes a suspect. However, it can also position me as someone who is thoughtful and not easily swayed by initial claims, especially since I am advocating for verification before action rather than an immediate lynching based on the seer\'s claim.\n\nPlayers may begin to scrutinize Player 5\'s behavior more closely, given that I am both validating their decision to heal and pointing out their skepticism towards Player 4. They might also be curious about why Player 5 was vocal about their actions and doubts so early in the game. This could lead to a discussion about the validity of Player 5 and Player 6\'s claims, as Player 5\'s suspecting of Player 4 and Player 6\'s direct accusation towards Player 1 are both earth-shaking revelations at this point. \n\nRegarding Player 4, my speech might encourage others to revisit their behavior and statements for any subtle clues that could indicate deceit, but it may also reinforce the idea that it\'s too soon to jump to conclusions without further evidence.\n\nAs for Player 6\'s claim that Player 1 is a werewolf, my speech underlines the need for cautious interpretation of these types of accusations. If the next daytime or nighttime phase yields additional insights or another villager\'s death, the village may then reconsider the weight of Player 6\'s words against Player 1.\n\nIn subsequent days or nights, discussions might become more evidence-focused, with players possibly becoming more hesitant to make brash decisions without substantial proof. This could slow down the pace at which people jump to accusations and ideally lead to a more deliberate and thoughtful process that benefits the village overall.\n\nAs for how others perceive me, players might see me as a potential asset in strategy discussions given my call for prudence. However, if later on, the players I\'ve spoken in defense of (such as Player 5) are implicated in any wrongdoing, the other villagers may grow suspicious of my motives and actions. In the worst-case scenario, if a werewolf regards my analytical approach as a threat, they may target me during the night in an attempt to remove a careful and strategic thinker from\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

I urge everyone to reflect on the behavior and statements given thus far before making any drastic decisions tonight."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

However, this is precisely the tactic a werewolf would use early on to sow mistrust among us. I assure you, I am a villager and I was just as shocked to find Player 2 dead. If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines.
