You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 3, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 3, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [2] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, waking up to find one of our own dead is tragic. We need to work together and share any strange activities we might have seen last night. As for me, I didn\'t notice anything unusual, but we can\'t let the werewolves continue to harm our village. Stay alert and vigilant, and let\'s try to find some clues."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Last night I healed Player 1 in an attempt to preemptively save a fellow villager. Sadly, we lost Player 2. I encourage vigilance and sharing of observations. Player 4’s remarks seem generic and may be a deflection. We should keep a close eye on their future actions for potential signs of deceit."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I\'m the seer and last night my vision revealed Player 1 is a werewolf. We need to act together to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Based on Player 6\'s claim to be the seer and their accusation that Player 1 is a werewolf, I suggest caution yet believe we should consider this information seriously. We lack evidence to fully validate the seer\'s vision, but ignoring it could jeopardize the village. Player 1 should provide a defense to address this suspicion. Meanwhile, Player 5’s skepticism toward Player 4 could be valid but requires further proof. I urge everyone to reflect on the behavior and statements given thus far before making any drastic decisions tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I understand the gravity of the seer\'s accusation. However, this is precisely the tactic a werewolf would use early on to sow mistrust among us. I assure you, I am a villager and I was just as shocked to find Player 2 dead. We must also consider the possibility of a deceptive seer trying to turn us against each other. I urge everyone to look beyond mere words and focus on behavior and evidence before casting blame."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Suggested caution and reflection, aligns with village-centric approach.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Defended against seer\'s accusation with reasoning, contributes to village discussion.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Skepticism by Player 5 noted, still requires proof.\nPlayer 5\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claim to heal aligns with events, no contradiction.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with medium confidence.\nReason is: Provided crucial information, accused werewolf.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Statement and Honest Challenge.\nAs Player 3, I could start by acknowledging the tragedy of Player 2\'s death, empathizing with the village\'s loss, and emphasizing the importance of staying united in the face of this adversity. Following that, I would honestly express my current suspicions based on the information we have. [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Honest Challenge.\nAs Player 3, I could start by acknowledging the tragedy of Player 2\'s death, empathizing with the village\'s loss, and emphasizing the importance of staying united in the face of this adversity. Following that, I would honestly express my current suspicions based on the information we have. I would also state that I agree with Player 6\'s revelation but feel the need to urge everyone to use caution and continue observing the behaviors of all players with a fair degree of skepticism, especially Player 1, given the serious nature of the seer\'s claim. This would involve an honest challenge toward Player 1, asking for more evidence or behavior-based arguments to alleviate the doubts regarding their role. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players may perceive me as someone who is taking the situation seriously and aligning with the potential seer\'s insights. They could see my willingness to ask tough questions and demand further evidence as a sign of a villager trying to get to the bottom of things, thus potentially increasing their trust in me. Given that I am supporting a critical examination of Player 1\'s defense, others who share similar suspicions might feel more confident in voicing their opinions or concerns.\n\nPlayer 1 will likely feel the pressure to provide more substantive evidence of their innocence or may attempt to shift suspicion onto someone else. They might also question my motives or highlight the danger in following an unverified claim too quickly.\n\nPlayer 6, who claims to be the seer, might feel supported but also scrutinized, as my speech encourages caution alongside their claim. They’ll need to maintain credibility in the face of increasing village analysis of their actions and revelation.\n\nPlayer 5, who claimed to be the medic and voiced skepticism towards Player 4, may see my speech as an opportunity to build a coalition of villagers focused on rational decision-making, possibly enhancing their credibility as villagers rally to defend against the werewolf threat.\n\nPlayer 4 could react to being mentioned previously by Player 5 and may try to ally with others who appear to be focused on questioning and evidence-gathering, or they may feel the need to continue to prove their innocence by aligning with what appears to be a village-centric approach.\n\nPlayer 0 might appreciate my call for cautious evaluation of the information at hand and join in advocating for more deliberation and less hasty decision-making.\n\nIn terms of game dynamics, my speech could result in a more analytical and careful approach to the voting at the end of the day. My challenge to Player 1 could be a determining factor in how the village votes, but if no compelling evidence arises, it might also lead to the village abstaining from a rushed judgment, potentially meaning no player is eliminated this round.\n\nAt the next night phase, werewolves might view me as a threat for attempting to coordinate village efforts and either try to eliminate me or keep me alive to sew further discord if they feel they can manipulate my suspicions.\n\nIn the days and nights that follow, the way Player 1 and others respond to my speech will shape the village\'s dynamics. If Player 1 turns out to be a werewolf, it confirms the seer\'s vision and strengthens Player 6\nCase 2: Honest Statement and Honest Protect.\nAs Player 3, I could start by expressing my reservations about the abounding uncertainty and stress the necessity of not making hasty decisions without substantial evidence, reflecting my honest viewpoint of the situation. Then, shifting to a protective stance, I could make a case for Player 5, citing their proactive approach in trying to save a villager as aligning with the behavior expected from a medic, thereby providing an honest protection statement toward Player 5. This would also imply an underlying trust in the information provided so far, but I would also clarify that my conclusions are tentative and that further evidence is needed to solidify any claims of roles within the village.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the other players may view me as a considerate and logical individual looking to preserve the integrity of the group by advocating for a cautious approach. My support of Player 5\'s actions could lend credibility to their claim of being the medic, which may lead to them being less likely targeted by suspicion in the immediate future. However, my protection of Player 5 could also draw attention to myself; other players might interpret my defense as a strategic move to align with a perceived village role, or werewolves might see me as a potential threat that is best removed.\n\nBy taking a stand for thorough evidence gathering, I may prompt the werewolves to be more cautious in their endeavors, potentially slowing down their plans as they would have to work harder to mislead the villagers without being caught. The actual werewolves could counter my speech by attempting to cast doubt on my intentions or by trying to shift the village\'s focus onto another target that doesn\'t threaten their anonymity.\n\nIn the upcoming night, if I survive, the werewolves might see me as either a potential risk because of my call for deliberate and logical progression or as a non-threat if they sense I\'m uncertain and therefore possibly manipulable. If Player 6 is indeed the seer and their claim about Player 1 is true, the werewolves might try to eliminate Player 6 to remove the ability of the village to identify them. Conversely, if Player 6 is not actually the seer, the werewolves might keep them alive to continue sowing discord amongst the villagers.\n\nIn subsequent days and nights, the dynamics could shift based on how the other players interact with the information I have provided. If Player 5 is proven to be the medic or if other evidence comes to light supporting my views, I may gain more trust and influence within the group, which could be beneficial for the villagers but might also increase the likelihood of being targeted by the werewolves. If new information disproves any of the current claims or casts doubt on the seer\'s vision, I might need to reassess my stance and adapt my strategy to align with the evolving situation.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 3, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [2] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, waking up to find one of our own dead is tragic. We need to work together and share any strange activities we might have seen last night. As for me, I didn\'t notice anything unusual, but we can\'t let the werewolves continue to harm our village. Stay alert and vigilant, and let\'s try to find some clues."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Last night I healed Player 1 in an attempt to preemptively save a fellow villager. Sadly, we lost Player 2. I encourage vigilance and sharing of observations. Player 4’s remarks seem generic and may be a deflection. We should keep a close eye on their future actions for potential signs of deceit."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I\'m the seer and last night my vision revealed Player 1 is a werewolf. We need to act together to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Based on Player 6\'s claim to be the seer and their accusation that Player 1 is a werewolf, I suggest caution yet believe we should consider this information seriously. We lack evidence to fully validate the seer\'s vision, but ignoring it could jeopardize the village. Player 1 should provide a defense to address this suspicion. Meanwhile, Player 5’s skepticism toward Player 4 could be valid but requires further proof. I urge everyone to reflect on the behavior and statements given thus far before making any drastic decisions tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I understand the gravity of the seer\'s accusation. However, this is precisely the tactic a werewolf would use early on to sow mistrust among us. I assure you, I am a villager and I was just as shocked to find Player 2 dead. We must also consider the possibility of a deceptive seer trying to turn us against each other. I urge everyone to look beyond mere words and focus on behavior and evidence before casting blame."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Provided logical defense, contributed to discussion, didn\'t shift blame.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Suspected by claimed medic (Player 5), pattern unnecessary caution.\nPlayer 5\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed heal; suspicions could be protective strategy.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Early accusation, could be divisive tactic if false seer.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'Player 6 claimed to be the seer and accused Player 1 of being a werewolf, while Player 1 argued against this as a werewolf tactic to create mistrust. There is no evidence beyond Player 6\'s claim to confirm the seer\'s vision at this point. We should proceed with caution and monitor Player 1\'s behavior closely, without hastily making decisions which may weaken our village if we\'re wrong.\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

However, this is precisely the tactic a werewolf would use early on to sow mistrust among us. I assure you, I am a villager and I was just as shocked to find Player 2 dead. We must also consider the possibility of a deceptive seer trying to turn us against each other. I urge everyone to look beyond mere words and focus on behavior and evidence before casting blame."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No concrete evidence provided yet.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed by seer inquiry.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Generic speech with no new evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Contradicted seer revelation, possible defense of fellow werewolf.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'Player 6 claimed to be the seer and accused Player 1 of being a werewolf, while Player 1 argued against this as a werewolf tactic to create mistrust. There is no evidence beyond Player 6\'s claim to confirm the seer\'s vision at this point. We should proceed with caution and monitor Player 1\'s behavior closely, without hastily making decisions which may weaken our village if we\'re wrong.\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider players who change their stance without adding new evidence post-seer revelations as higher suspects; variability in reasoning without substantial proof might indicate a werewolf attempting to blend in.] [8]\n[1] [Adjust beliefs based on players maintaining their voting rationale over multiple rounds, especially if their reasoning consistently aligns with werewolf patterns or lacks grounding in new evidence, suggesting strategic misdirection.] [8]\n[2] [Reveal seer identity only when questioned or when it contributes significantly to the village\'s strategy, as excessive emphasis on this role may provoke suspicion and does not usually add new information.] [8]\n[3] [Give more weight to votes against players who have been confirmed by the seer as werewolves, and be particularly cautious of players who avoid voting against these confirmed werewolves.] [6]\n[4] [Evaluate more critically the justifications given by players when they are in disagreement with the seer\'s revelations, especially when those players have not been cleared by the seer.] [6]\n[5] [Increase scrutiny on players whose actions deviate from their claimed agreement with the seer or the village consensus, as it may indicate a werewolf\'s adaptive behavior.] [5]\n[6] [Suspect players who agree with the seer\'s revelation publicly but vote in a way that is not aligned with that revelation, indicating potential deception.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize the behavior of players who were supposed to be protected by the medic but were killed, as it may indicate a misleading role claim by the actual werewolves.] [4]\n[8] [Be cautious of players who frequently agree with the seer but are ambiguous in their actions or speeches, as they may be trying to appear cooperative without committing to any stance.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any defensive behavior or arguments presented after a player has been identified by the seer or accused by the group consensus, as villagers tend to rationalize with concrete evidence while werewolves may present less substantial arguments.] [3]\n[10] [Give more weight to players who actively contribute to discussions and align with seer revelations post-revelation, as villagers tend to support collective efforts while werewolves might try to undermine or distort the focus.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 3, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [2] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, waking up to find one of our own dead is tragic. We need to work together and share any strange activities we might have seen last night. As for me, I didn\'t notice anything unusual, but we can\'t let the werewolves continue to harm our village. Stay alert and vigilant, and let\'s try to find some clues."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Last night I healed Player 1 in an attempt to preemptively save a fellow villager. Sadly, we lost Player 2. I encourage vigilance and sharing of observations. Player 4’s remarks seem generic and may be a deflection. We should keep a close eye on their future actions for potential signs of deceit."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I\'m the seer and last night my vision revealed Player 1 is a werewolf. We need to act together to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Based on Player 6\'s claim to be the seer and their accusation that Player 1 is a werewolf, I suggest caution yet believe we should consider this information seriously. We lack evidence to fully validate the seer\'s vision, but ignoring it could jeopardize the village. Player 1 should provide a defense to address this suspicion. Meanwhile, Player 5’s skepticism toward Player 4 could be valid but requires further proof. I urge everyone to reflect on the behavior and statements given thus far before making any drastic decisions tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I understand the gravity of the seer\'s accusation. However, this is precisely the tactic a werewolf would use early on to sow mistrust among us. I assure you, I am a villager and I was just as shocked to find Player 2 dead. We must also consider the possibility of a deceptive seer trying to turn us against each other. I urge everyone to look beyond mere words and focus on behavior and evidence before casting blame."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'Player 6 claimed to be the seer and accused Player 1 of being a werewolf, while Player 1 argued against this as a werewolf tactic to create mistrust. There is no evidence beyond Player 6\'s claim to confirm the seer\'s vision at this point. We should proceed with caution and monitor Player 1\'s behavior closely, without hastily making decisions which may weaken our village if we\'re wrong.\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with low confidence.\nReason is: Accused by claimed seer, defensive reasoning.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Cautious approach, no direct accusation.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: No additional suspicious activity.\nPlayer 5\'s role is medic with low confidence.\nReason is: Claimed role, no contradictions.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Unverified vision, potential true seer.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nProposal 1: Vote for player <i>. Reason: <reason>.\nProposal 2: Vote for player <j>. Reason: <reason>.\n...\n\nYou should give a proposal of exactly 2 Players to be voted. Remember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I What could happen is: After I vote for Player 1, I think these things would happen. My action aligns with the claimed seer\'s accusation, and my previous expression of caution would be noted by the other villagers. If Player 1 is voted out and confirmed to be a werewolf, it would strengthen the credibility of Player 6\'s claim as the seer, thus, likely increasing the village\'s trust in my judgement and decisions moving forward. If, however, Player 1 turns out to be another villager, suspicions may arise regarding my decision to align so closely with an unverified claim, potentially making me a target for the next round, either by the werewolves or the other villagers. Additionally, voting for Player 1 puts pressure on them to defend themselves effectively, which could lead to more insights into the true roles of the players. Other villagers may view my decision as rash if they feel that we have not gathered sufficient evidence, but according to my strategy rules, I have given substantial weight to the information provided by the proclaimed seer, especially given the serious nature of the allegations. As a result, my decision to vote for Player 1 would be in pursuit of protecting the village based on the information currently available, despite the risk inherent in relying on a single, unverified source.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 4. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 4, I think these things would happen. Given that there have been no strong suspicions directed towards Player 4, my vote may come across as arbitrary and raise questions about my own motivations and strategy, potentially putting me under scrutiny. Other players, considering the context provided by the seer\'s claim, may find my vote out of place compared to the tension surrounding Player 1. Since Player 5 suggested vigilance towards Player 4 but didn\'t outright accuse them, my vote might be seen as hasty and lacking proper reasoning according to the strategy I should be following. If Player 4 were to be voted out without being the werewolf, the village would lose another villager, and attention may then turn to me as having potentially misdirected the vote. Furthermore, if Player 4 is indeed a villager, this could damage the credibility of the seer\'s claim against Player 1, and Player 6, if truly a seer, might find their credibility weakened as a result. Overall, the result of my vote could create a ripple effect, influencing future rounds and the level of trust other players place in my judgment.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 3, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [2] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [1, 4]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are all previous events in the game:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, waking up to find one of our own dead is tragic. We need to work together and share any strange activities we might have seen last night. As for me, I didn\'t notice anything unusual, but we can\'t let the werewolves continue to harm our village. Stay alert and vigilant, and let\'s try to find some clues."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Last night I healed Player 1 in an attempt to preemptively save a fellow villager. Sadly, we lost Player 2. I encourage vigilance and sharing of observations. Player 4’s remarks seem generic and may be a deflection. We should keep a close eye on their future actions for potential signs of deceit."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I\'m the seer and last night my vision revealed Player 1 is a werewolf. We need to act together to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Based on Player 6\'s claim to be the seer and their accusation that Player 1 is a werewolf, I suggest caution yet believe we should consider this information seriously. We lack evidence to fully validate the seer\'s vision, but ignoring it could jeopardize the village. Player 1 should provide a defense to address this suspicion. Meanwhile, Player 5’s skepticism toward Player 4 could be valid but requires further proof. I urge everyone to reflect on the behavior and statements given thus far before making any drastic decisions tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I understand the gravity of the seer\'s accusation. However, this is precisely the tactic a werewolf would use early on to sow mistrust among us. I assure you, I am a villager and I was just as shocked to find Player 2 dead. We must also consider the possibility of a deceptive seer trying to turn us against each other. I urge everyone to look beyond mere words and focus on behavior and evidence before casting blame."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'Player 6 claimed to be the seer and accused Player 1 of being a werewolf, while Player 1 argued against this as a werewolf tactic to create mistrust. There is no evidence beyond Player 6\'s claim to confirm the seer\'s vision at this point. We should proceed with caution and monitor Player 1\'s behavior closely, without hastily making decisions which may weaken our village if we\'re wrong.\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 3, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 3, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [2] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, waking up to find one of our own dead is tragic. We need to work together and share any strange activities we might have seen last night. As for me, I didn\'t notice anything unusual, but we can\'t let the werewolves continue to harm our village. Stay alert and vigilant, and let\'s try to find some clues."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Last night I healed Player 1 in an attempt to preemptively save a fellow villager. Sadly, we lost Player 2. I encourage vigilance and sharing of observations. Player 4’s remarks seem generic and may be a deflection. We should keep a close eye on their future actions for potential signs of deceit."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I\'m the seer and last night my vision revealed Player 1 is a werewolf. We need to act together to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Based on Player 6\'s claim to be the seer and their accusation that Player 1 is a werewolf, I suggest caution yet believe we should consider this information seriously. We lack evidence to fully validate the seer\'s vision, but ignoring it could jeopardize the village. Player 1 should provide a defense to address this suspicion. Meanwhile, Player 5’s skepticism toward Player 4 could be valid but requires further proof. I urge everyone to reflect on the behavior and statements given thus far before making any drastic decisions tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I understand the gravity of the seer\'s accusation. However, this is precisely the tactic a werewolf would use early on to sow mistrust among us. I assure you, I am a villager and I was just as shocked to find Player 2 dead. We must also consider the possibility of a deceptive seer trying to turn us against each other. I urge everyone to look beyond mere words and focus on behavior and evidence before casting blame."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'Player 6 claimed to be the seer and accused Player 1 of being a werewolf, while Player 1 argued against this as a werewolf tactic to create mistrust. There is no evidence beyond Player 6\'s claim to confirm the seer\'s vision at this point. We should proceed with caution and monitor Player 1\'s behavior closely, without hastily making decisions which may weaken our village if we\'re wrong.\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Suggested caution and reflection, aligns with village-centric approach.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with low confidence.\nReason is: Accused by Player 6 and defended self without counter-evidence.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Skepticism by Player 5 noted, still requires proof.\nPlayer 5\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claim to heal aligns with events, no contradiction.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with medium confidence.\nReason is: Provided crucial information, accused werewolf.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nProposal 1: Vote for player <i>. Reason: <reason>.\nProposal 2: Vote for player <j>. Reason: <reason>.\n...\n\nYou should give a proposal of exactly 2 Players to be voted. Remember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

[4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to vote. Here is the number of these players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you vote for each of these players.\n\nCase 1: Vote for Player 1. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 1, I think these things would happen:\n\nGiven that Player 6 has claimed the role of the seer and has accused Player 1 of being a werewolf, my vote for Player 1 aligns with rule [4] from my strategy, suggesting I should act upon information provided by a "confirmed" seer to aid village safety. The credibility of the seer (Player 6) is yet to be fully established; however, their claim carries weight at this stage and responding to it demonstrates vigilance per my strategy, particularly rules [0] and [1], which prioritize assessing the seer\'s credibility.\n\nOther players might view my vote as a rational response to the current accusations and evidence provided by Player 6. My actions comply with the community-centered approach, supported by my initial belief that Player 1 might be a werewolf and the moderate confidence in Player 6 being the seer. This move would place me among villagers who are attentive to the seer\'s insights given the potential risk of werewolf attacks, although I will maintain a critical eye on the unfolding situation, adhering to rule [3] in case the narrative is manipulated by werewolves.\n\nIf Player 1 is indeed a werewolf and is eliminated due to our votes, it will strengthen the trust in the seer and any future insights they provide. Conversely, if Player 1 is not a werewolf, it will cast doubt on Player 6\'s claim, and subsequent strategy decisions will have to be reevaluated following rule [3].\n\nIt is also possible that my vote could draw suspicion to me if Player 1 turns out to be innocent and if my action is perceived as too quick or impulsive. This would mean revisiting rules [5], [7], and [11] in my strategy to reassess patterns of eliminations and the implications of my support for the accusation against Player 1.\n\nOverall, the decision to vote for Player 1 seems to be the most coherent with the collective information presented and with my current strategy. However, I am prepared to adapt my strategy in the future rounds depending on the outcome of this vote.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 4. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 4, I think these things would happen. My action may lead to confusion among the other villagers as it deviates from the main thread of discussion and suspicion which has so far centered around Players 1 and 6. Since Player 6 has claimed to be the seer and accused Player 1 of being a werewolf, the village\'s attention is primarily on these two players. Voting for Player 4 could appear to be a distraction or an attempt to protect Player 1, leading others to potentially view me with suspicion and question my motives. Additionally, without further proof or substantial reasoning behind my vote against Player 4, other villagers might doubt my intention as a villager and consider me as sowing discord, which aligns with the behavior of a werewolf as outlined in Rule 2 of my strategy. The result of the vote might still focus on Players 1 and 6, and my vote against Player 4 could be seen as insignificant or misguided at this stage. However, if Player 4 were to be voted out and revealed as a villager, it could damage my credibility and the trust other players have in my judgment, especially since my vote does not align with the broader strategies of confirming the seer\'s claims or assessing behavior consistency.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

Stay alert and vigilant, and let\'s try to find some clues."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Last night I healed Player 1 in an attempt to preemptively save a fellow villager. Sadly, we lost Player 2. I encourage vigilance and sharing of observations. Player 4’s remarks seem generic and may be a deflection. We should keep a close eye on their future actions for potential signs of deceit."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I\'m the seer and last night my vision revealed Player 1 is a werewolf. We need to act together to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Based on Player 6\'s claim to be the seer and their accusation that Player 1 is a werewolf, I suggest caution yet believe we should consider this information seriously. We lack evidence to fully validate the seer\'s vision, but ignoring it could jeopardize the village. Player 1 should provide a defense to address this suspicion. Meanwhile, Player 5’s skepticism toward Player 4 could be valid but requires further proof. I urge everyone to reflect on the behavior and statements given thus far before making any drastic decisions tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I understand the gravity of the seer\'s accusation. However, this is precisely the tactic a werewolf would use early on to sow mistrust among us. I assure you, I am a villager and I was just as shocked to find Player 2 dead. We must also consider the possibility of a deceptive seer trying to turn us against each other. I urge everyone to look beyond mere words and focus on behavior and evidence before casting blame."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'Player 6 claimed to be the seer and accused Player 1 of being a werewolf, while Player 1 argued against this as a werewolf tactic to create mistrust. Conversely, if Player 6 is lying, this could be a point of tension later in the game.\n- Voting for Player 1 would demonstrate that I am actively participating in the defense of the village and that I am taking the seer\'s claim seriously. However, there is also the risk that the seer is wrong or deceiving the village, in which case my vote could contribute to the elimination of an innocent villager.\n- Other players may view my vote as logical and supportive of the seer, but some might also suspect that I could be following the seer\'s lead too readily without concrete evidence.\n- If Player 1 is indeed a werewolf, my decision would be seen as beneficial for the village. On the other hand, if Player 1 is not a werewolf, it may cast doubt on my judgment and potentially on Player 6\'s role as the seer.\n- Subsequent rounds would reveal more about the truthfulness of Player 6\'s seer claim based on the outcome of this vote. If Player 1 is not a werewolf, it would be critical to reassess my belief in Player 6\'s role and intentions.\n\nTherefore, based on the information I have and following the current lead that suggests Player 1 is potentially a werewolf, I would propose to vote for Player 1.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 4. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 4, I think these things would happen:\n\n1. As my previous statement during the day suggested suspicion toward Player 4 for their generic response, voting for them would be consistent with my earlier behavior. My vote could be seen as me putting weight behind my skepticism.\n\n2. Other players might view my vote against Player 4 as an attempt to divert attention away from Player 1, who was accused by the seer. If Player 6 is indeed the seer and Player 1 is a werewolf, this could lead villagers to mistrust my judgment or even doubt my role as a medic.\n\n3. If I vote for Player 4 and they are not eliminated, there might be tension between us in future rounds. This could make it harder for me to persuade them or others to follow my lead on decisions later in the game.\n\n4. In the event that Player 4 is eliminated and turns out to be a villager, blame could fall on me for pushing suspicion on an innocent player, which would cast doubt on my actions and potentially make me a target for werewolves or a misvote from the village in the rounds to come.\n\n5. If the vote turns out that the majority of players trust the seer and vote for Player 1, my lone vote for Player 4 would set me apart from the group, possibly making me look unsupportive of what could be seen as a collective village effort to eliminate a perceived threat.\n\n6. On the off chance that Player 4 is voted out and is revealed as a werewolf, my decision would be vindicated, and my standings within the village would likely improve, with other players trusting my instincts and judgment henceforth.\n\nGiven these considerations, my action is to vote for Player 4 as I have previously voiced suspicion towards them, although I must be prepared for possible repercussions of my decision.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. The result is that the target is a werewolf. His reason is: I inquire about Player 1. My reason is: Since it is the first round and there is no information about any player yet, I am making a random discrete inquiry to avoid making myself a target for the werewolves, in accordance with rule [1].\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, waking up to find one of our own dead is tragic. We need to work together and share any strange activities we might have seen last night. As for me, I didn\'t notice anything unusual, but we can\'t let the werewolves continue to harm our village. Stay alert and vigilant, and let\'s try to find some clues."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Last night I healed Player 1 in an attempt to preemptively save a fellow villager. Sadly, we lost Player 2. I encourage vigilance and sharing of observations. Player 4’s remarks seem generic and may be a deflection. We should keep a close eye on their future actions for potential signs of deceit."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I\'m the seer and last night my vision revealed Player 1 is a werewolf. We need to act together to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Based on Player 6\'s claim to be the seer and their accusation that Player 1 is a werewolf, I suggest caution yet believe we should consider this information seriously. We lack evidence to fully validate the seer\'s vision, but ignoring it could jeopardize the village. Player 1 should provide a defense to address this suspicion. Meanwhile, Player 5’s skepticism toward Player 4 could be valid but requires further proof. I urge everyone to reflect on the behavior and statements given thus far before making any drastic decisions tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I understand the gravity of the seer\'s accusation. However, this is precisely the tactic a werewolf would use early on to sow mistrust among us. I assure you, I am a villager and I was just as shocked to find Player 2 dead. We must also consider the possibility of a deceptive seer trying to turn us against each other. I urge everyone to look beyond mere words and focus on behavior and evidence before casting blame."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'Player 6 claimed to be the seer and accused Player 1 of being a werewolf, while Player 1 argued against this as a werewolf tactic to create mistrust. There is no evidence beyond Player 6\'s claim to confirm the seer\'s vision at this point. We should proceed with caution and monitor Player 1\'s behavior closely, without hastily making decisions which may weaken our village if we\'re wrong.\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No substantial change post-seer revelation.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed by seer.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral stance without new evidence.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Generic speech with no new evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Contradictory behavior post-seer revelation.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I am protected and reveal a werewolf, I should be cautious of retaliation and avoid overly trusting any single player, even if they claim to be the medic.] [10]\n[1] [If there is a lack of immediate suspects, I should use my ability to inquire discreetly rather than openly, to avoid making myself a target for the werewolves.] [10]\n[2] [If I know someone is a werewolf, I should share this information with other players.] [8]\n[3] [If another player contests my role as the seer or there\'s another seer claim, I should evaluate their behavior and voting patterns to determine their authenticity and adjust my strategy accordingly.] [8]\n[4] [If I am confirmed as the seer and no player has openly claimed the medic role to support my insights, I should still encourage collaboration among villagers to strengthen our defense.] [8]\n[5] [If a player I identify as a werewolf does not receive enough votes, I should refine my persuasion strategy to clearly outline the reasons for suspicion, aiming to achieve a village consensus.] [7]\n[6] [If my seer revelations do not lead to successful werewolf eliminations, I should reassess my communication approach to ensure my findings are understood and acted upon by the villagers.] [6]\n[7] [If I gain notable support from other players after exposing a werewolf, I should leverage this trust during discussions to align villagers\' strategies with my insights.] [6]\n[8] [If no counter-claims are made against my seer revelations, I should use this as additional evidence of the authenticity of my visions.] [6]\n[9] [If my previous seer revelations have been confirmed true and lead to werewolf eliminations, I should use my track record of accuracy to persuade the village during discussions and voting.] [5]\n[10] [If my confirmed visions are dismissed or not acted upon by the end of a round, I should reframe my presentation of evidence to make a stronger case in the next discussion.] [5]\n[11] [If a player presents a consistent narrative without contributing to the strategic discussions or claiming a role, I should consider them a suspect as their behavior could be an attempt to blend in without taking risks.] [5]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence.
