You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[1] [I am the only medic.] [10]\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

All players currently alive are: [0, 3, 4, 5], which indicates that [2, 1, 6] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, waking up to find one of our own dead is tragic. We need to work together and share any strange activities we might have seen last night. As for me, I didn\'t notice anything unusual, but we can\'t let the werewolves continue to harm our village. Stay alert and vigilant, and let\'s try to find some clues."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Last night I healed Player 1 in an attempt to preemptively save a fellow villager. Sadly, we lost Player 2. I encourage vigilance and sharing of observations. Player 4’s remarks seem generic and may be a deflection. We should keep a close eye on their future actions for potential signs of deceit."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I\'m the seer and last night my vision revealed Player 1 is a werewolf. We need to act together to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Based on Player 6\'s claim to be the seer and their accusation that Player 1 is a werewolf, I suggest caution yet believe we should consider this information seriously. We lack evidence to fully validate the seer\'s vision, but ignoring it could jeopardize the village. Player 1 should provide a defense to address this suspicion. Meanwhile, Player 5’s skepticism toward Player 4 could be valid but requires further proof. I urge everyone to reflect on the behavior and statements given thus far before making any drastic decisions tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I understand the gravity of the seer\'s accusation. However, this is precisely the tactic a werewolf would use early on to sow mistrust among us. I assure you, I am a villager and I was just as shocked to find Player 2 dead. We must also consider the possibility of a deceptive seer trying to turn us against each other. I urge everyone to look beyond mere words and focus on behavior and evidence before casting blame."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'Player 6 claimed to be the seer and accused Player 1 of being a werewolf, while Player 1 argued against this as a werewolf tactic to create mistrust. There is no evidence beyond Player 6\'s claim to confirm the seer\'s vision at this point. We should proceed with caution and monitor Player 1\'s behavior closely, without hastily making decisions which may weaken our village if we\'re wrong.\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 3 votes for player 1. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 1. My reason is that voting for them is consistent with both the seer\'s accusation and my original strategy. While the credibility of Player 6 as the seer isn\'t fully confirmed, it is important to respond to the possibility of a villager being a werewolf to maintain village safety, as suggested by rule [4]. Player 6\'s claim is the most tangible piece of evidence we have at the moment, and acting upon it demonstrates vigilance as prioritized in rules [0] and [1] of my strategy. A vote against Player 1 is a strategic choice that aligns with the current information provided and is a move to protect the village, while still allowing me to reassess and adapt my strategy in future rounds depending on the outcome of this vote.\nEvent: Player 1 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Given the unfortunate demise of Player 6, who claimed to be the seer and pointed to Player 1 as a werewolf, it\'s logical to consider the likelihood of Player 4\'s involvement, as they were untouched by the seer\'s claim. Player 4\'s generic statements earlier do not alleviate suspicion. I have performed my duty as medic, aiming to protect those who might be targeted by the werewolves based on logical deductions. It\'s imperative we scrutinize Player 4\'s actions and assess their alignment with the village\'s safety."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 4 has been silent since the seer\'s accusation and subsequent death. Despite the seer targeting Player 1, who was voted out, Player 4\'s subtle approach and undisturbed status merit suspicion. Player 5, who claims to be the medic, has actively participated and pinpointed concerns, while Player 4\'s input was generic. This pattern is concerning; it could indicate a strategic silence to avoid detection. Given these observations, we should closely examine Player 4\'s actions and consider them a candidate for our vote."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistently supports village, aligns with actual events, adds depth.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with low confidence.\nReason is: Accused by Player 6 and defended self without counter-evidence.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Remained untargeted, silence after seer\'s accusation, no substantial input.\nPlayer 5\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Active participation, logical medic behavior, targets threats based on deduction.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with medium confidence.\nReason is: Accusation led to werewolf\'s elimination.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Protect and Statement.\n"It is apparent that the role of the medic is of utmost importance in our predicament, and Player 5 has consistently demonstrated behavior in line with that critical role. Their active participation and logical deductions have contributed to the protection of our villagers and the identification of potential threats. In light of this, I stand by the belief that Player 5\'s intentions and actions align with our collective goal of preserving our village. As we move forward, it is crucial that we consider all available information, allowing us to formulate our decisions and speak openly against deceit while upholding our values of honesty and protection."\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Challenge and Statement.\n"Given the tragic loss of Player 6, who bravely took on the role of seer and sadly met his demise, I find it increasingly hard to ignore the suspicions around Player 4. The silence from Player 4 following the seer\'s accusation is deafening, coming across as a strategy to remain undetected. Furthermore, their initial generic statements do little to affirm their innocence. While I am committed to the careful consideration of evidence, Player 4 has yet to provide a compelling argument for their behavior, which has now become a pattern worth challenging. We must be cohesive and rational in our approach to safeguard our village.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players may consider my points and scrutinize Player 4 more closely, given the alignment with earlier doubts expressed by Players 0 and 5. They may appreciate my commitment to following logic and evidence, which corroborates my consistent behavior as a villager. This can lead to increased trust in my judgment amongst the remaining villagers.\n\nPlayer 4 might feel pressured to defend themselves and could either provide a substantial defense or attempt to deflect suspicion onto me or Player 5. Player 5 might support my challenge against Player 4, reinforcing the suspicions due to their earlier expressed doubts. \n\nPlayer 0, who has been cautious and analytical, may weigh in on my challenge with their insights, maintaining their objective stance. This player may also appreciate my use of logic and evidence, as it aligns with their own approach to the game.\n\nIn the next day or night, if Player 4 is indeed a werewolf and if my challenge gains traction, the werewolves might perceive me as a threat for pinpointing one of their own. This could lead to my elimination during the night phase as werewolves may try to remove villagers who are effective at identifying them. However, if Player 4 is a villager, my incorrect challenge may cause some distrust towards my judgment, although my consistency and use of logic could mitigate this.\n\nIn subsequent rounds, how the remaining players react to my speech could greatly influence the game\'s direction. If I survive the night, I may need to continue building upon my strategy, re-analyzing my fellow players, and maintaining vigilance to protect the village. If Player 4 ends up being eliminated and is confirmed as a werewolf, my reputation as a reliable villager would be strengthened, making me an asset to the village but also a target for the werewolves.\nCase 2: Honest Protect and Statement.\n"It is apparent that the role of the medic is of utmost importance in our predicament, and Player 5 has consistently demonstrated behavior in line with that critical role. Their active participation and logical deductions have contributed to the protection of our villagers and the identification of potential threats. In light of this, I stand by the belief that Player 5\'s intentions and actions align with our collective goal of preserving our village. As we move forward, it is crucial that we consider all available information, allowing us to formulate our decisions and speak openly against deceit while upholding our values of honesty and protection.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the following may unfold:\n\nPlayer 0 and Player 5 might perceive my defense of Player 5 as reinforcing the logic behind my own decision-making and solidifying trust amongst us. If Player 5 is indeed the medic, my validation of their role could lead to a strengthened alliance between the villagers.\n\nGiven my analysis and the events so far, Player 4, who I suspect to be a werewolf, might feel compelled to either counter my assertions or attempt to deflect suspicion onto another player, possibly myself. Player 4 could become more active in the discussion to disrupt the growing consensus about their potential werewolf identity.\n\nOther players may appreciate the consistency of my approach, upholding the principles laid out in my original strategy. By emphasizing the need for honesty and diligence, I reinforce my position as a trustworthy member of the village, which might encourage others to be more open in sharing their observations and thoughts, leading to a more informed decision-making process.\n\nIn the next day or night phase, werewolves could target Player 5, claiming to be the medic, to eliminate the protection they provide. However, since my speech draws attention to the importance of the medic\'s role, the werewolves might also consider not targeting Player 5 to avoid confirming my suspicions and instead focus on removing another villager who is less suspected to blur the lines and spread confusion among the remaining villagers.\n\nIf I survive to the next round, other players might look to me for further leadership and insight, as my speech suggests a proactive and protective stance that could be seen as valuable for the village\'s survival. On the other hand, werewolves might see me as a threat due to my analytical approach and decide to rally against me or even target me in the following night phase, aiming to weaken the villagers\' strategic capabilities.\n\nIn summary, my speech is likely to solidify the current alliances and suspicions, provoke reactions from Player 4, and potentially influence the werewolves\' strategies in the coming phases of the game, all while boosting my credibility and role as a protector of the village.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

They have remained silent since the accusations, offering no defense or contribution to our discussions. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Given these observations, we should closely examine Player 4\'s actions and consider them a candidate for our vote."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Considering the unfortunate death of Player 6, who claimed the seer\'s role, and the subsequent absence of suspicion on Player 4, I voice my concerns regarding Player 4\'s behavior. They have remained silent since the accusations, offering no defense or contribution to our discussions. This pattern stands in stark contrast to the proactivity shown by Player 5, whose actions are consistent with what we would expect from the medic. Player 0 has been analytical and cautious, not quick to judge without substantiated evidence. In light of these observations and our shared objective to protect the village, we must scrutinize Player 4\'s silence following the seer\'s accusation and consider it a significant factor as we move forward."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Analytical and cautious, aligns with events.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Defensive; challenges seer without new evidence.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Encourages evidence-based decisions, contrasts Player 4\'s silence.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Silent post-accusations, contrasts with village proactivity.\nPlayer 5\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Active participation, logical reasoning aligns with claimed role.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with high confidence.\nReason is: Accusation led to werewolf being voted out.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, my silence was borne from shock and reflection, not guilt. I voted Player 6 not because of their seer claim, but due to the possibility of falsifying that role to sow discord. My earlier generic statement was an attempt to not seem overzealous, which often backfires. I recognize the suspicion on me yet I assure you, I stand with the village. We must focus on behaviors and patterns, not just words. I urge us to think carefully; our survival depends on unity and clear judgment."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

It\'s imperative we scrutinize Player 4\'s actions and assess their alignment with the village\'s safety."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 4 has been silent since the seer\'s accusation and subsequent death. Despite the seer targeting Player 1, who was voted out, Player 4\'s subtle approach and undisturbed status merit suspicion. Player 5, who claims to be the medic, has actively participated and pinpointed concerns, while Player 4\'s input was generic. This pattern is concerning; it could indicate a strategic silence to avoid detection. Given these observations, we should closely examine Player 4\'s actions and consider them a candidate for our vote."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Considering the unfortunate death of Player 6, who claimed the seer\'s role, and the subsequent absence of suspicion on Player 4, I voice my concerns regarding Player 4\'s behavior. They have remained silent since the accusations, offering no defense or contribution to our discussions. This pattern stands in stark contrast to the proactivity shown by Player 5, whose actions are consistent with what we would expect from the medic. Player 0 has been analytical and cautious, not quick to judge without substantiated evidence. In light of these observations and our shared objective to protect the village, we must scrutinize Player 4\'s silence following the seer\'s accusation and consider it a significant factor as we move forward."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Analytical, cautious, and aligns with seer revelations.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed by seer.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Questions Player 4 based on visible events and patterns.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Silent post-seer accusation and suspected by multiple players.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Cleared by seer and consistent medic behavior.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, my silence was borne from shock and reflection, not guilt. I voted Player 6 not because of their seer claim, but due to the possibility of falsifying that role to sow discord. My earlier generic statement was an attempt to not seem overzealous, which often backfires. I recognize the suspicion on me yet I assure you, I stand with the village. We must focus on behaviors and patterns, not just words. I urge us to think carefully; our survival depends on unity and clear judgment."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider players who change their stance without adding new evidence post-seer revelations as higher suspects; variability in reasoning without substantial proof might indicate a werewolf attempting to blend in.] [8]\n[1] [Adjust beliefs based on players maintaining their voting rationale over multiple rounds, especially if their reasoning consistently aligns with werewolf patterns or lacks grounding in new evidence, suggesting strategic misdirection.] [8]\n[2] [Reveal seer identity only when questioned or when it contributes significantly to the village\'s strategy, as excessive emphasis on this role may provoke suspicion and does not usually add new information.] [8]\n[3] [Give more weight to votes against players who have been confirmed by the seer as werewolves, and be particularly cautious of players who avoid voting against these confirmed werewolves.] [6]\n[4] [Evaluate more critically the justifications given by players when they are in disagreement with the seer\'s revelations, especially when those players have not been cleared by the seer.] [6]\n[5] [Increase scrutiny on players whose actions deviate from their claimed agreement with the seer or the village consensus, as it may indicate a werewolf\'s adaptive behavior.] [5]\n[6] [Suspect players who agree with the seer\'s revelation publicly but vote in a way that is not aligned with that revelation, indicating potential deception.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize the behavior of players who were supposed to be protected by the medic but were killed, as it may indicate a misleading role claim by the actual werewolves.] [4]\n[8] [Be cautious of players who frequently agree with the seer but are ambiguous in their actions or speeches, as they may be trying to appear cooperative without committing to any stance.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any defensive behavior or arguments presented after a player has been identified by the seer or accused by the group consensus, as villagers tend to rationalize with concrete evidence while werewolves may present less substantial arguments.] [3]\n[10] [Give more weight to players who actively contribute to discussions and align with seer revelations post-revelation, as villagers tend to support collective efforts while werewolves might try to undermine or distort the focus.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 3, 4, 5], which indicates that [2, 1, 6] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, waking up to find one of our own dead is tragic. We need to work together and share any strange activities we might have seen last night. As for me, I didn\'t notice anything unusual, but we can\'t let the werewolves continue to harm our village. Stay alert and vigilant, and let\'s try to find some clues."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Last night I healed Player 1 in an attempt to preemptively save a fellow villager. Sadly, we lost Player 2. I encourage vigilance and sharing of observations. Player 4’s remarks seem generic and may be a deflection. We should keep a close eye on their future actions for potential signs of deceit."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I\'m the seer and last night my vision revealed Player 1 is a werewolf. We need to act together to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Based on Player 6\'s claim to be the seer and their accusation that Player 1 is a werewolf, I suggest caution yet believe we should consider this information seriously. We lack evidence to fully validate the seer\'s vision, but ignoring it could jeopardize the village. Player 1 should provide a defense to address this suspicion. Meanwhile, Player 5’s skepticism toward Player 4 could be valid but requires further proof. I urge everyone to reflect on the behavior and statements given thus far before making any drastic decisions tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I understand the gravity of the seer\'s accusation. However, this is precisely the tactic a werewolf would use early on to sow mistrust among us. I assure you, I am a villager and I was just as shocked to find Player 2 dead. We must also consider the possibility of a deceptive seer trying to turn us against each other. I urge everyone to look beyond mere words and focus on behavior and evidence before casting blame."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'Player 6 claimed to be the seer and accused Player 1 of being a werewolf, while Player 1 argued against this as a werewolf tactic to create mistrust. There is no evidence beyond Player 6\'s claim to confirm the seer\'s vision at this point. We should proceed with caution and monitor Player 1\'s behavior closely, without hastily making decisions which may weaken our village if we\'re wrong.\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 1. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 1. My reason is that the vote aligns with the apparent vision of the claimed seer, Player 6, and adheres to my outlined strategy, particularly rule [4], which focuses on acting upon information provided by a player identified as the seer. While the credibility of Player 6 as the seer is not yet confirmed and my confidence in Player 1 being a werewolf is low, the severeness of the accusation and the potential risk to the village if ignored warrants consideration. Voting for Player 1 addresses rules [0] and [3] in my strategy, acknowledging the need to reassess the credibility of the seer\'s insights and consider the ramifications of the vote. This decision is made despite the inherent risks, under the provision of acting in the village\'s best interest with the current available information.\nEvent: Player 1 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Given the unfortunate demise of Player 6, who claimed to be the seer and pointed to Player 1 as a werewolf, it\'s logical to consider the likelihood of Player 4\'s involvement, as they were untouched by the seer\'s claim. Player 4\'s generic statements earlier do not alleviate suspicion. I have performed my duty as medic, aiming to protect those who might be targeted by the werewolves based on logical deductions. It\'s imperative we scrutinize Player 4\'s actions and assess their alignment with the village\'s safety."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 4 has been silent since the seer\'s accusation and subsequent death. Despite the seer targeting Player 1, who was voted out, Player 4\'s subtle approach and undisturbed status merit suspicion. Player 5, who claims to be the medic, has actively participated and pinpointed concerns, while Player 4\'s input was generic. This pattern is concerning; it could indicate a strategic silence to avoid detection. Given these observations, we should closely examine Player 4\'s actions and consider them a candidate for our vote."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Considering the unfortunate death of Player 6, who claimed the seer\'s role, and the subsequent absence of suspicion on Player 4, I voice my concerns regarding Player 4\'s behavior. They have remained silent since the accusations, offering no defense or contribution to our discussions. This pattern stands in stark contrast to the proactivity shown by Player 5, whose actions are consistent with what we would expect from the medic. Player 0 has been analytical and cautious, not quick to judge without substantiated evidence. In light of these observations and our shared objective to protect the village, we must scrutinize Player 4\'s silence following the seer\'s accusation and consider it a significant factor as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, my silence was borne from shock and reflection, not guilt. I voted Player 6 not because of their seer claim, but due to the possibility of falsifying that role to sow discord. My earlier generic statement was an attempt to not seem overzealous, which often backfires. I recognize the suspicion on me yet I assure you, I stand with the village. We must focus on behaviors and patterns, not just words. I urge us to think carefully; our survival depends on unity and clear judgment."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with low confidence.\nReason is: Accused by claimed seer, defensive reasoning.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with events, logical contribution, seeks evidence-based judgment.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Defensive after silence and voting against seer claimant without solid reasoning.\nPlayer 5\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Uncontested claim, consistent village defense, post-seer death engagement.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Died after revealing vision, might have been real seer.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nProposal 1: Vote for player <i>. Reason: <reason>.\nProposal 2: Vote for player <j>. Reason: <reason>.\n...\n\nYou should give a proposal of exactly 2 Players to be voted. Remember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

My earlier generic statement was an attempt to not seem overzealous, which often backfires. I recognize the suspicion on me yet I assure you, I stand with the village. We must focus on behaviors and patterns, not just words. I urge us to think carefully; our survival depends on unity and clear judgment."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with low confidence.\nReason is: Accused by claimed seer, defensive reasoning.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with events, logical contribution, seeks evidence-based judgment.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Defensive after silence and voting against seer claimant without solid reasoning.\nPlayer 5\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Uncontested claim, consistent village defense, post-seer death engagement.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Died after revealing vision, might have been real seer.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 1 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. \n\nYou are considering to vote for Player 3. Please analyze and imagine what may happen after you vote for this Player 3. This includes what the result of the vote might be, as well as what would other player think about you after they see your voting for Player 3.\n\nYour answer should be in the format of:\n\n\nAfter I vote for Player 3, I think these things would happen. <YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 3, 4, 5], which indicates that [2, 1, 6] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, waking up to find one of our own dead is tragic. We need to work together and share any strange activities we might have seen last night. As for me, I didn\'t notice anything unusual, but we can\'t let the werewolves continue to harm our village. Stay alert and vigilant, and let\'s try to find some clues."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Last night I healed Player 1 in an attempt to preemptively save a fellow villager. Sadly, we lost Player 2. I encourage vigilance and sharing of observations. Player 4’s remarks seem generic and may be a deflection. We should keep a close eye on their future actions for potential signs of deceit."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I\'m the seer and last night my vision revealed Player 1 is a werewolf. We need to act together to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Based on Player 6\'s claim to be the seer and their accusation that Player 1 is a werewolf, I suggest caution yet believe we should consider this information seriously. We lack evidence to fully validate the seer\'s vision, but ignoring it could jeopardize the village. Player 1 should provide a defense to address this suspicion. Meanwhile, Player 5’s skepticism toward Player 4 could be valid but requires further proof. I urge everyone to reflect on the behavior and statements given thus far before making any drastic decisions tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I understand the gravity of the seer\'s accusation. However, this is precisely the tactic a werewolf would use early on to sow mistrust among us. I assure you, I am a villager and I was just as shocked to find Player 2 dead. We must also consider the possibility of a deceptive seer trying to turn us against each other. I urge everyone to look beyond mere words and focus on behavior and evidence before casting blame."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'Player 6 claimed to be the seer and accused Player 1 of being a werewolf, while Player 1 argued against this as a werewolf tactic to create mistrust. There is no evidence beyond Player 6\'s claim to confirm the seer\'s vision at this point. We should proceed with caution and monitor Player 1\'s behavior closely, without hastily making decisions which may weaken our village if we\'re wrong.\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 1. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 1. My reason is that the vote aligns with the apparent vision of the claimed seer, Player 6, and adheres to my outlined strategy, particularly rule [4], which focuses on acting upon information provided by a player identified as the seer. While the credibility of Player 6 as the seer is not yet confirmed and my confidence in Player 1 being a werewolf is low, the severeness of the accusation and the potential risk to the village if ignored warrants consideration. Voting for Player 1 addresses rules [0] and [3] in my strategy, acknowledging the need to reassess the credibility of the seer\'s insights and consider the ramifications of the vote. This decision is made despite the inherent risks, under the provision of acting in the village\'s best interest with the current available information.\nEvent: Player 1 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Given the unfortunate demise of Player 6, who claimed to be the seer and pointed to Player 1 as a werewolf, it\'s logical to consider the likelihood of Player 4\'s involvement, as they were untouched by the seer\'s claim. Player 4\'s generic statements earlier do not alleviate suspicion. I have performed my duty as medic, aiming to protect those who might be targeted by the werewolves based on logical deductions. It\'s imperative we scrutinize Player 4\'s actions and assess their alignment with the village\'s safety."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 4 has been silent since the seer\'s accusation and subsequent death. Despite the seer targeting Player 1, who was voted out, Player 4\'s subtle approach and undisturbed status merit suspicion. Player 5, who claims to be the medic, has actively participated and pinpointed concerns, while Player 4\'s input was generic. This pattern is concerning; it could indicate a strategic silence to avoid detection. Given these observations, we should closely examine Player 4\'s actions and consider them a candidate for our vote."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Considering the unfortunate death of Player 6, who claimed the seer\'s role, and the subsequent absence of suspicion on Player 4, I voice my concerns regarding Player 4\'s behavior. They have remained silent since the accusations, offering no defense or contribution to our discussions. This pattern stands in stark contrast to the proactivity shown by Player 5, whose actions are consistent with what we would expect from the medic. Player 0 has been analytical and cautious, not quick to judge without substantiated evidence. In light of these observations and our shared objective to protect the village, we must scrutinize Player 4\'s silence following the seer\'s accusation and consider it a significant factor as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, my silence was borne from shock and reflection, not guilt. I voted Player 6 not because of their seer claim, but due to the possibility of falsifying that role to sow discord. My earlier generic statement was an attempt to not seem overzealous, which often backfires. I recognize the suspicion on me yet I assure you, I stand with the village. We must focus on behaviors and patterns, not just words. I urge us to think carefully; our survival depends on unity and clear judgment."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with low confidence.\nReason is: Accused by claimed seer, defensive reasoning.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with events, logical contribution, seeks evidence-based judgment.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Defensive after silence and voting against seer claimant without solid reasoning.\nPlayer 5\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Uncontested claim, consistent village defense, post-seer death engagement.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Died after revealing vision, might have been real seer.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to vote. Here is the number of these players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you vote for each of these players.\n\nCase 1: Vote for Player 4. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 4, I think these things would happen. Player 4 would be voted out if my teammates agree with my assessment and vote similarly. Given the conversations and suspicions that have already been raised concerning Player 4\'s actions or lack thereof, it is likely that other players may also see Player 4 as a potential threat and align with this decision, resulting in their elimination. My voting for Player 4 aligns with rule [5], as their inconsistent behavior post-seer accusation is a potential indicator of their true role. It also matches with rule [2], since Player 4 voted against the seer claimant without providing a substantial reason, which could be seen as sowing doubt.\n\nIf Player 4 is indeed a werewolf, their elimination would contribute to village safety, adhering to rule [4]. Player 3 and Player 5 have expressed similar concerns, so it is reasonable to believe that they might support this vote. Subsequent to this vote, if Player 4 turns out to be a werewolf, it would validate my strategy and strengthen alliances with remaining villagers. However, if Player 4 is actually a villager, the remaining werewolf would likely target either me or Player 5 next, assuming Player 5 is truly the medic as they claim and cannot heal themselves again immediately.\n\nOther players might view me as being decisive and analytical, considering the strategy and rules I follow. They might appreciate the adherence to a logical and evidence-based approach towards identifying threats to the village. Conversely, if Player 4 is not a werewolf, others might doubt my judgment and the reliability of my strategy going forward, but given that my actions conform to our agreed-upon rules and my expressed reasoning, it should mitigate some of the suspicion on me. In any case, my decision to vote for Player 4 is made in the spirit of protecting the village based on the available information and past events.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 3. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 3, I think these things would happen. Player 3 would likely be surprised by my vote since there has been no solid evidence suggesting them as a werewolf. Moreover, given my earlier stated beliefs and the events that have transpired, players might question my alignment and reasoning. Player 3 has made logical contributions and maintained a behavior consistent with village safety, so my vote would go against my own stated strategy, particularly rules [2], [3], [7], [9], and [11]. Other players could perceive my vote as irrational or as an indication that I might be trying to protect Player 4, whom I previously suspected. This could lead to increased suspicion on myself in the next round if I am not eliminated. Additionally, given that I previously expressed high confidence in Player 3\'s role as a villager, voting for them without new evidence could undermine the coherence of my earlier arguments and create doubt in my credibility. This would also contradict rule [5] about the importance of consistency in player behavior as an indicator of their role and intentions. If Player 3 is voted out and is indeed a villager, this could leave me vulnerable to accusations of being a werewolf in the next round, as it would appear as though I had attempted to mislead the village. The result of the vote could critically impact the safety of the village by potentially removing an innocent villager instead of targeting the true threat.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

This pattern stands in stark contrast to the proactivity shown by Player 5, whose actions are consistent with what we would expect from the medic. Player 0 has been analytical and cautious, not quick to judge without substantiated evidence. In light of these observations and our shared objective to protect the village, we must scrutinize Player 4\'s silence following the seer\'s accusation and consider it a significant factor as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, my silence was borne from shock and reflection, not guilt. I voted Player 6 not because of their seer claim, but due to the possibility of falsifying that role to sow discord. My earlier generic statement was an attempt to not seem overzealous, which often backfires. I recognize the suspicion on me yet I assure you, I stand with the village. We must focus on behaviors and patterns, not just words. I urge us to think carefully; our survival depends on unity and clear judgment."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Continues to analyze and caution against rash judgments.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with low confidence.\nReason is: Accused by Player 6 and defended self without counter-evidence.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Provides explanation post-accusation but still under suspicion due to previous silence and voting pattern.\nPlayer 5\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Proactive in duty and logically aligns with the medic role suspects Player 4.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with medium confidence.\nReason is: Accusation led to werewolf\'s elimination.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 1 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. \n\nYou are considering to vote for Player 4. Please analyze and imagine what may happen after you vote for this Player 4. This includes what the result of the vote might be, as well as what would other player think about you after they see your voting for Player 4.\n\nYour answer should be in the format of:\n\n\nAfter I vote for Player 4, I think these things would happen. <YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

All players currently alive are: [0, 3, 4, 5], which indicates that [2, 1, 6] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, waking up to find one of our own dead is tragic. We need to work together and share any strange activities we might have seen last night. As for me, I didn\'t notice anything unusual, but we can\'t let the werewolves continue to harm our village. Stay alert and vigilant, and let\'s try to find some clues."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Last night I healed Player 1 in an attempt to preemptively save a fellow villager. Sadly, we lost Player 2. I encourage vigilance and sharing of observations. Player 4’s remarks seem generic and may be a deflection. We should keep a close eye on their future actions for potential signs of deceit."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I\'m the seer and last night my vision revealed Player 1 is a werewolf. We need to act together to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Based on Player 6\'s claim to be the seer and their accusation that Player 1 is a werewolf, I suggest caution yet believe we should consider this information seriously. We lack evidence to fully validate the seer\'s vision, but ignoring it could jeopardize the village. Player 1 should provide a defense to address this suspicion. Meanwhile, Player 5’s skepticism toward Player 4 could be valid but requires further proof. I urge everyone to reflect on the behavior and statements given thus far before making any drastic decisions tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I understand the gravity of the seer\'s accusation. I urge everyone to look beyond mere words and focus on behavior and evidence before casting blame."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'Player 6 claimed to be the seer and accused Player 1 of being a werewolf, while Player 1 argued against this as a werewolf tactic to create mistrust. There is no evidence beyond Player 6\'s claim to confirm the seer\'s vision at this point. We should proceed with caution and monitor Player 1\'s behavior closely, without hastily making decisions which may weaken our village if we\'re wrong.\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 3 votes for player 1. It\'s imperative we scrutinize Player 4\'s actions and assess their alignment with the village\'s safety."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 4 has been silent since the seer\'s accusation and subsequent death. Despite the seer targeting Player 1, who was voted out, Player 4\'s subtle approach and undisturbed status merit suspicion. This pattern is concerning; it could indicate a strategic silence to avoid detection. Given these observations, we should closely examine Player 4\'s actions and consider them a candidate for our vote."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Considering the unfortunate death of Player 6, who claimed the seer\'s role, and the subsequent absence of suspicion on Player 4, I voice my concerns regarding Player 4\'s behavior.
